posts.name: Dave
posts.cooked: As this season has progressed, our design subteam has been learning a lot, and we have been trying to tackle our own attempts at more advanced building and design techniques. One roadblock we have come across is the issue of pocketing material. Due to our proximity to the weight limit of each year rapidly increasing (especially this year), we decided that it was wise to research pocketing to potentially assist with that. However, we haven’t had much success when attempting to manually create the pocket shapes always seem to be too weak or do not save satisfactory weight. Additionally, we have not been able to find a clear answer for which program some teams use. I assume that there is an automated tool which higher level teams take advantage of, but there hasn’t been a clear answer that’s we’ve found. If anyone would like to please give some insight that would be greatly appreciated.

posts.name: Arshon Bozorgi
posts.cooked:
There is a lightening featurescript in onshape, as a part of “Julia’s Featurescripts.”

we have had good success using it this season, however it doesn’t generate a lightening pattern automatically. You have to define where you want to keep material.

you can find it linked here: Featurescripts | FRCDesign.org

Before you start pocketing, save weight by making the geometry more efficient. Cutting material on the outside of plates removes material that serves 0 structural purpose and is just weight reduction for free. Oftentimes, a beam can get you more strength for less weight than a plate, especially if bending is involved. Or better yet, avoid bending loads in the first place by using beams to convert bending into tension or compression.

Once you’ve done that, now its time to pocket. The goal of pocketing is to turn one plate into a bunch of little beams. For plates, connect all points of interest directly. These generally are screw and bearing holes, but may consist of other contact points This puts the individual beams in tension and compression, which is the direction beams are strong in. Avoid indirect connections whenever possible, as this puts individual struts in bending which is much weaker. Use large radii, as small radii create pretty bad stress risers and prevent the use of larger endmills.

For boxtube, just don’t pocket them unless you know what you are doing. There are very few scenarios where pocketing boxtube is weight efficient, and all of them require clean loading conditions, which is rare in FRC .

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked: I’m interested in more detail about your last point.  Pocketed tubes are universal in larger sizes used for telescoping arms, for example (2910, 233, etc).  How should teams decide when pocketed tubes are appropriate?

posts.name: James O’Leary
posts.cooked: What i’ve been taught is dont pocket tube unless you have to. I was also told that pocketed 1/8" is weaker than unpocketed 1/16"

posts.name: Chris Bale
posts.cooked:
JamesO1086:

I was also told that pocketed 1/8" is weaker than unpocketed 1/16"

This is a pretty broad statement. “Pocketing” is not one universal thing, both the type and density of the pattern affects the strength, as does as the load direction.

cbale2000:

This is a pretty broad statement. “Pocketing” is not one universal thing, both the type and density of the pattern affects the strength, as does as the load direction.

Yet it is mostly true. The word that is missing is “weight-normalized”. Any pocketing adds stress risers, which significantly increase the stress experienced by a beam. For reference, a hole on an infinite plane in tension increases the local stress by 3x. The stress risers created by pocketing are boxtube are worse than a hole on an infinite plane as boxtube is far from infinite and there are localized behaviors that are problematic.

Since 1/8th tube isn’t even 2x as strong as 1/16th tube, adding any stress riser makes you close to or weaker than the 1/16th tube, while still being about double the weight. There is a way to pocket boxtube without weakening it, but it doesn’t end up removing very much material (maybe like 10 or 20% removed at best), in which the 1/16th tube still is more weight efficient.

truher:

I’m interested in more detail about your last point. Pocketed tubes are universal in larger sizes used for telescoping arms, for example (2910, 233, etc). How should teams decide when pocketed tubes are appropriate?

TL:DR never in practice unless you don’t care about strength at all.

Consider cantilever boxtube under uniaxial bending. The stress increases as you approach the support, so you can pocket the far end of the boxtube to not increase stress on the spots that matter. FEA actually can answer the “how far away do the slots need to be away from the support?”

Now consider the beam profile. Suppose the uniaxial bending direction is down. If you pocket the sides of the boxtube, you turn the one large beam with a good 2nd moment area into two beams in parable with very bad 2nd moment areas, as the splitting the beam both removes effective material that is far away, and shifts the centroid right next to the material that used to be far material, so this loses like an order of magnitude of strength or more. So pocketing the sides even a little bit is very bad for this reason.

Now to consider the top. The best pattern to use are large radius holes or slots, as they have a large radius which results in reduced stress concentration. Triangle patters are bad as they have sharper corners, which creates worse stress risers which now make them the weakest point of the beam, even if they are far from the supports.

But notice how I’ve always said uniaxial bending. The slots on the top/bottom pattern is equivalent to splitting the beam for as long as possible when loaded sideways, which as I previously mentioned is very bad. In FRC , you rarely get to pick how your robot gets impacted, as your driver or auto can sometimes mess up, and opposing robots are completely out of your control (a red card does not physically prevent robots from reaching into you and causing damage). With the exception of extremely well-designed climbers, there are no mechanisms in FRC where you really get to pick the direction they get loaded in if there is robot to robot interaction, which results in all pocketing effectively being the bad case of splitting the beam in two.

2910 and 1323 got away with pocketing boxtube this year because defense wasn’t viable, meaning they really didn’t care how strong their structures were. In this case, they just needed as much stuff to mount to for minimal weight, in which you can get away with strength-inefficent patterns.

posts.name: Henry Becker
posts.cooked:
We skeletonized all of the 1/8" and 1/16" 1x2 tube on our elevator with no issues. it saved us around 8 Lbs iirc. image 377×791 83.3 KB

image 377×791 83.3 KB

image 377×791 83.3 KB

posts.name: Corbin Kuster
posts.cooked: I’m hoping to do this to our elevator in the offseason. Would you mind sharing the rib and wall thickness you used, and maybe the weight of your end effector for reference?

posts.name: Devin Castellucci
posts.cooked:
The fact that you had no issues with it means you could have gone even lighter with non pocketed tubing. If you had success with the 1/16th pocketed you could easily run 0.040" wall tube(I swear someone in the FRC sphere was selling 040 tubes) which is probably similar weight savings. Even just shaving down the walls yourself gives a stronger end product. If you have any 1/8 wall in your elevator you should just use 1/16" and just put hole in it.

Every year I am always walking the pits and telling teams that you can get away with much thinner wall tube 90% of the time with a little planning.

posts.name: Ben Edwards
posts.cooked:
That must have been a lot of pocketing.  1 x 2 x 0.125" tube weighs 0.067 lb/inch, 1 x 2 x 0.063" tube weighs 0.0354 lb/inch.

Looking at your machine it’s I guess 3 tubes / side at 36" or so each, plus the carriage and crossbars which might be another 72" total.  If you used thin wall tube it’s only 10 pounds or so before pocketing…  man.  that’s REALLY aggressive pocketing.

Thick wall it’s a different story - around 19 pounds of tubing - but then you’re doing a lot of pocketing to basically get you down to thin wall weight.

I’m inclined to agree with others that pocketing tubing doesn’t make a ton of sense, unless and you’re truly desperate for ounces.  Thinner walls get you more strength and less effort.

Has somebody actually verified how thin you can reasonably go? There comes a point where the walls get so thin that the primary failure mode becomes localized buckling of the sides rather than yeilding via flexural stress.We see thin round tube all the time because round tube is hard to buckle, but I haven’t ever seen somebody use .4 tubing outside of maxtube, which is problematic for other reasons.

posts.name: Henry Becker
posts.cooked: We needed it. we were 115.0 lbs

posts.name: Calvin Selin
posts.cooked: I would recommend 2471’s Part Lighten Featurescript.  It offers more control over everything than julia’s lighten.  If you want to use large patterns, I would suggest using the cheeseit! featurescript to create ribs, then use the part lighten to actually lighten it.

posts.name: Henry Becker
posts.cooked: Sign in to Onshape, the #1 fastest growing CAD system in the world with over 4 million users.

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked:
@Alex_Y I generally agree with your main point about tubes, which I think is that it’s always better to increase radius and decrease wall thickness, until the “panel stiffness” of the tube becomes the limiting factor.  Beam stiffness goes as the cube of radius, and mass is only linear.

I suspect one reason we see so many small pocketed tubes in FRC is that there aren’t good templates for resolving point loads, like “lugs” or “hard points” in a space frame.  My own team made some nice light arm tubes a couple of years ago, but the joints exhibited buckling and deformation.  It’s easier to overgauge the tube, and drill a hole in it, than to engineer a fancy bracket with a socket.  Do you know of good examples we might be able to use for teaching about thinner, bigger tubes with better brackets?

posts.name: Ryan Stockton
posts.cooked:
We ran the .040" thick wall REV 2x1 Maxtube on the fixed and moving stages of our elevator this year. The thin tubes were plenty strong and we didn’t experience any localized deformation where the elevator bearings rode over 122 matches this year.

Stiffness is what we were chasing. We saw .030" of deflection at the top of the fixed stage of the elevator with a 7 pound applied load. FEA was used to analyze several options for stiffening the tubes and by far the most mass efficient was adding carbon fiber sheets to the 1" face of the fixed elevator rails. We used sheets of 1/16" carbon fiber (what we had on hand at the time) epoxied together to prevent slip between the sheets and riveted to the tubing. The sheets are “stair stepped” to minimize weight as carbon fiber further up the tube doesn’t add as much to the stiffness as it does right above where the elevator A-frame ends. IMG_2770 719×959 177 KB

IMG_2770 719×959 177 KB

IMG_2770 719×959 177 KB

By adding 3/8 of a pound of carbon fiber and rivets we were able to get the deflection of the .040" wall tubing to be very similar to the deflection of .080" wall tubing which was about .015"

Below is a photo of the measurement setup: att.1-iHYSb-j59-sFSZPGS26SW5u-XpSqIdtBlJXygpU5g 1438×1918 398 KB

att.1-iHYSb-j59-sFSZPGS26SW5u-XpSqIdtBlJXygpU5g 1438×1918 398 KB

att.1-iHYSb-j59-sFSZPGS26SW5u-XpSqIdtBlJXygpU5g 1438×1918 398 KB

If REV doesn’t change their shipping practices plan on about 20% of the tubing being unusable for an elevator. Quite a few of the tubes we received were bent across the whole length or were damaged on the ends due to there being no packing material around the tubing at all. Overall we were happy with the REV tubing on the robot, we would have been overweight if we had to use 1/16" wall tubing.

IMG_1729 1438×1918 372 KB

IMG_1729 1438×1918 372 KB
